headline: Your cookie preferences
sentences: This is just a small subset of the bank's overall holdings, but we still found dozens of dubious characters in the data, including an Algerian general accused of torture, the children of a brutal Azerbaijani strongman, and even a Serbian drug lord known as Misha Banana.
Through our partner, German newspaper Süddeutsche Zeitung, OCCRP obtained leaked records on more than 18,000 Credit Suisse accounts, the largest leak ever from a major Swiss bank.
When corrupt politicians or organized criminals turn to Switzerland to keep their money safe from prying eyes, the victims of their crimes will likely never see it again.
Switzerland's draconian banking secrecy laws have made it nearly impossible for other governments or journalists to hold the industry to account.
Swiss banks have been synonymous with secrecy for decades, conjuring up visions of vast riches safely held in mountain vaults.
Read on to learn more about what we — and our media partners on five continents — found in the data.
It's a strong brand — one Switzerland's government does everything it can to protect.
And once dirty money makes it into a Swiss bank account, it's free to go anywhere.
But what's good for the banks' wealthy clients can be bad for everyone else.
